channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dispatches From the Hong Kong Protest Zone
item.description: On Thursday morning, the Hong Kong police moved in to clear away the encampment of pro-democracy protesters who had occupied streets near government offices for 10 weeks.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators displayed a huge banner on Wednesday in the final hours before the police were to clear the protest site.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Coverage of C.I.A. Torture Report Says It Highlights U.S. Hypocrisy
item.description: The state-run news media weighed in with photographs and analysis, including details of extreme interrogation techniques used by the C.I.A., such as waterboarding.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: An editorial cartoon in the English-language China Daily commented on the repercussions of the report on the C.I.A.'s interrogation tactics.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Begin Removing Protesters as Dismantling of Camp Proceeds
item.description: Dozens of the most prominent members of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movement offered themselves up for arrest on Thursday in a show of shared defiance.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The police removed a demonstrator from a protest site outside government headquarters in Hong Kong on Thursday.

item.title: Liu Xiaobo, Nobel-Winning Chinese Dissident, Said to Send Message From Prison
item.description: A Berlin-based friend of Liu Xiaobo, who is serving an 11-year sentence in Beijing, said he had a received a message from him through contacts in China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Liu Xiaobo in an undated photo released by his family in 2010. He has been imprisoned since 2008.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Woman Charged in One of a String of Deaths
item.description: Prosecutors charged Chisako Kakehi, 68, on Wednesday with murdering her husband, one of at least six men who have died while in a relationship with her.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: The Hague: Court Seeks U.N. Help in Qaddafi Case
item.description: Judges at the International Criminal Court ruled Wednesday that Libya had failed to comply with court orders relating to Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of the former Libyan dictator, and referred the matter to the United Nations Security Council.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: World Briefing: Monaco: Twins Are Born to Royal Couple
item.description: Cannons were fired on Wednesday in celebration after twins were born to Prince Albert II, 56, and Princess Charlene, 36.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Conflicting Accounts Rise in Failed Hostage Rescue
item.description: The official account of a mission to rescue an American hostage being held by the Qaeda affiliate in Yemen was impossible to reconcile with villagers’ accounts.
item.dc:creator: By SAEED AL BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Drug Trade Transforms an Amazon Outpost
item.description: The city of Manaus is reeling from expanding drug violence, including the targeting of the police and grisly murders in gang turf wars.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A masked police officer in Manaus, Brazil, conducted a raid on a home in Beco Cruzeiro do Sul, a slum where cocaine dealers are thought to operate.

item.title: U.S. Tells Court That Documents From Torture Investigation Should Remain Secret
item.description: The New York Times has filed a request that the Justice Department disclose documents from an investigation into C.I.A. torture of detainees, including summaries of interviews with witnesses and documents explaining why no charges were filed.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Pentagon to Press Russia on Arms Pact Violation
item.description: The aim is to persuade Russia to address the Obama administration’s accusation that it has developed a ground-launched cruise missile in violation of a 1987 treaty.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Rose Gottemoeller of the State Department said the administration was also considering “economic countermeasures.”

item.title: Workers in Hong Kong Begin Dismantling Main Protest Camp
item.description: Dozens of police and court bailiffs watched as the workers dismantled road barriers built from metal railings by demonstrators to protect their street camp in Admiralty, next to the city government offices.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Workers removed barricades on Thursday morning at the main pro-democracy protest camp in Hong Kong.

item.title: A Top Target of China’s Graft Purge Gets Life in Prison
item.description: Liu Tienan was one of the first and most visible targets of the push by President Xi Jinping to take down both “tigers” and “flies” — powerful and minor officials.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Americans Involved in Torture Can Be Prosecuted Abroad, Analysts Say
item.description: Calls for international prosecution, legal experts say, are likely to grow so long as the United States chooses not to prosecute its own.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: C.I.A. First Planned Jails Abiding by U.S. Standards
item.description: The agency envisioned a system in which detainees would be offered the same rights and protections as inmates held in federal or American military prisons.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO and JAMES RISEN
item.media:description: Donald Rumsfeld is said to have ruled out military jails.

item.title: Torture Report Puts Presidential Hopefuls in Quiet Mode
item.description: Most of the presumptive presidential candidates have not plunged into Washington’s debate over the Senate Intelligence Committee’s withering report on the C.I.A.’s brutal interrogation tactics.
item.dc:creator: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and MICHAEL BARBARO
item.media:description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has not spoken out on the Senate report.

item.title: Op-Docs: ‘Toys of War’
item.description: In a refugee camp in South Sudan, children make a dollhouse to tell their story of war.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW BERENDS

item.title: Karl Otto Pöhl, a Former President of the German Central Bank, Dies at 85
item.description: Mr. Pöhl had a fixation on price stability that still guides eurozone monetary policy and was an anti-inflation hawk.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Karl Otto Pöhl in 1998 in Zurich.

item.title: News Analysis: Putin, Shunned by West, Visits India, a Friend Whose Interests May Lie Elsewhere
item.description: The two nations were bound throughout the Cold War by a mutual mistrust of the United States, though there is now some uncertainty in the old relationship.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At Climate Meeting, China Balks at Verifying Cuts in Carbon Emissions
item.description: Officials have sometimes referred to a 24-year-old clause that says countries should have “common but differentiated responsibilities,” meaning developed and developing nations have different standards to meet when it comes to taking action on climate change.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Smog obscures the skyline in Shenyang, Liaoning Province. Populist anger over toxic smog has convinced some Chinese leaders that industrial coal consumption must be curbed.
